medium: Ink and light colors on silk
title: Landscape After Huang Kung-Wang
text:
Born in Hangchou, Lan Ying at an early age was determined to become a famous painter. While classified as a highly skilled professional artist, perhaps the last important Che school painter, Lan Ying also had deep historical knowledge of past painting styles. He had close contact with literati luminaries like Sun Ke-hung (1532-1610), Tung Ch'i-ch'ang, and Chen Chi-ju (1558-1639) who shared their opinions with the younger artist and opened their collections of old paintings to him.

Lan Ying was essentially a professional painter however, and this work depicting a summer landscape shows more decorative brushwork, richer colors, and mannered landscape elements than typically encountered in the Ch'ing orthodox tradition. Be this as it may, Lan Ying still pays homage to past literati masters by referencing the famous fourteenth century master, Huang Kung-Wang, in his inscription.
description: mountains in background, dotted with trees; buildings with 3 figures in foreground; pine trees throughout
creditline: Gift of Ruth and Bruce Dayton
